Title: Infographic: The effects of COVID-19 on perioperative morbidity and mortality in patients with hip fractures
Abstract: © 2020 The British Editorial Society of Bone & Joint Surgery.Despite significant changes in social behaviour during the COVID-19 pandemic, the incidence of fragility fractures remains unchanged.1,2 Nearly one in two patients with perioperative SARS-CoV-2 infection will develop postoperative respiratory complications. which is associated with high levels of mortality.3 As a large proportion of hip fracture patients are known to present with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 carriage,4 health services have been required to find novel solutions to adjust to the "new normal".5 Such changes can lead to treatment delays, a known risk factor for mortality in an increasingly frail and elderly population.6 The true impact of COVID-19 pandemic on perioperative outcomes in high-risk hip fracture patients remains uncertain. This multicentre cohort study reports on risk factors associated with perioperative morbidity and mortality in 422 patients (340 COVID-19-negative vs 82 COVID-19-positive) undergoing hip fracture surgery during the pandemic. Treatment groups were comparable for age, sex, body mass index, fracture configuration, and type of surgery performed. Predefined perioperative outcomes were recorded within a 30-day postoperative period. Univariate and multivariate Cox proportional hazard modelling was used to identify risk factors associated with increased risk of mortality. COVID-19-positive patients had increased postoperative mortality rates compared to COVID- 19- negative patients (30.5% (25/82) vs 10.3% (35/340) respectively, p < 0.001). Risk factors for increased perioperative mortality in patients with COVID-19 included positive smoking status (hazard ratio (HR) 15.4 (95% confidence interval (CI) 4.55 to 52.2; p < 0.001) and greater than three medical comorbidities (HR 13.5 (95% CI 2.82 to 66.0, p < 0.001). COVID-19-positive patients had increased risk of postoperative complications (89.0% (73/82) vs 35.0% (119/340) respectively; p < 0.001), more critical care unit admissions (61.0% (50/82) versus 18.2% (62/340) respectively; p < 0.001), and increased length of hospital stay (mean 13.8 days (standard deviation (SD) 4.6) versus 6.7 days (SD 2.5) respectively; p < 0.001), compared to COVID-19-negative patients. Hip fracture surgery in COVID-19-positive patients is associated with increased perioperative morbidity and mortality rates compared to COVID-19-negative patients. Risk factors for increased mortality in patients with COVID-19 undergoing surgery included positive smoking status and multiple (more than three) comorbidities.
